body:
Thinking out loud.

I think there should be the UI views that derive from each other
- ChatApplicationView
  - OverviewView
  - ChatView
    - ChannelView
    - ChatView
      - ChatTitleView
      - ChatWordsView
      - ChatInputView
    - UserListView
      - UserListTitleView
      - UserListDisplayView (Need to think of a better name)
I went ahead and put in @akavlie 's work on this I forgot to tag the commit for this issue.
btw, I have a decent solution for the JS resizing on window resize in web-irc.
I like the idea of speech bubbles but it doesn't always work so well with lots of messages. I also like the idea of 37signals campfire esque messages.
I _really_ like the animated scroll. I think it looks great, but it does call issues when you have multiple messages. What about having a smaller time for the new messages to scroll?
At the very least you should be able to turn off the showing the date. I feel like this could be a checkbox on the input box.
Looking at campfire screenshots... yeah, that's not bad as an inspiration (without directly copying). It's sensible, but not necessarily attractive.

Note here are some of the different ideas:
- http://www.solutionwatch.com/images/office_campfire_chat_full.gif
- http://watchingapple.com/wp-content/uploads/2007/05/ichat-tabs.png
- http://dribbble.com/shots/349379-Skype-chat-in-my-world
- http://dribbble.com/shots/194068-More-chat-console-interface-UX-UI

I like it as well. A shorter scroll time will help a bit, but won't really solve the underlying problem for motd -- we're getting a flood of individual events for every line, rather than a single scroll event for the whole thing. May be able to solve this with some logic.
I guess you really should be only scrolling to the last recieved message.
We'll say that at this point this is good.
Those two dribble shots are pretty good; I like quite a few aspects of those (but not everything). Moreso the Skype chat example than the other.
I will try to work something out. I think its really good idea to keep the background of the chat contents white though.

ACTION input is supported in node-irc, but not events (for output). There's an outstanding pull request to add support:
https://github.com/martynsmith/node-irc/pull/58

I'll bug Martyn about it if he doesn't get around to it soon.
Why pull requests? Are you working off of a fork somewhere?
No I just wanted you to see the code before I merged it. It gives me a little bit more accountability.
If you wanted me just to merge branches though I am fine doing that too.

Ah, OK. Didn't realize you could do pull requests from/to one and the same repository.
I'll look it over.
I feel like this is more or less ready to be merged. I would like a way though for the user to define regexs and colors to be alerted. I guess that is a feature for later down the line.
Good work @akavlie done.
The new UI addresses these issues.

as in, "incorrect server address".

Will ask Martyn if a new release is coming.
Asked Martyn about this one via email.
Could we put this in a try catch block?

I don't think so; the failure is up in node.js somewhere because an error
event isn't defined. I'm not sure it's possible to do a try/catch block
within our code to deal with that.

The fix is already in node-irc; we can wait for the new version on npm or
point our packages to github if there isn't a new version soon.

On Thu, Jan 12, 2012 at 11:28 PM, David Petersen <
reply@reply.github.com

> wrote:

> 
> ---
>

freelance web development
aaron.kavlie.net
We can process these ourselves, I did it in the subway-web code.

I only see support for sending a /me message (the easy case). Did you do anything with incoming messages? That's a bit trickier.

May code it in if the code isn't merged into node-irc soon, but looking for events from node-irc would make for simpler and more consistent code.
If you filter on the first characters of the stream, you just have to look for the 'ACTION' string.

Here is the line in subway-web:

https://github.com/thedjpetersen/subway-web/blob/master/assets/javascripts/subway_views.js#L13
Done -- moved into ChatView

Tried it, min-width doesn't seem to work here.
Methinks fluid layout everywhere is problematic.
I think the chat contents should resize fluidly, but most other elements would be better off with fixed sizing.

Added support for /part command. Don't yet have a graphic.
If I add that, it will be a lame placeholder until @thedjpetersen does it right  ;-)
Think the chat window model/view also need to be removed.
Its only a problem with the logo correct?
The only real problem is with the logo correct?

I need to design the logo...getting around to it. Someday?

/part should work without a channel, and just quit the current active channel, and set the active channel to the last one in the list.
Yes and no... the sidebar needs a minimum width to show the logo, as well as channel names and unread counts.

You're going to design a new logo?? Saying that that will come before X buttons on tabs or something? I'm confused...

For active channel after parting, I'm setting it to the previous one in the list, unless that's status. Some variation of "nearest tab" seems more sensible than last tab -- most tab UIs will do nearest to left or right.
No I am just saying that it is on my things to do. I think that is sensible to do the nearest one.
At what resolution would the percentage resolution become a problem?
I just tested it out, and it starts cutting off when the window is about 645px wide. Granted, that's narrower than users would typically be sizing their browser windows (other than on mobile).
Replace the scrollTo plugin with this.
are you seeing a lot of CPU consumption from that feature?
If you don't have any objections, I think I'll try a version of the layout without percentage sizing, and port my window resizing code from web-irc.
Pull request submitted.
Looks good. Merging.
I'll checkout the code and get back to you as soon as possible.
I'll leave the 'x' buttons to you.
Pull request submitted.
Looks fine, I am not sure of the best practices for having your package.json file.
I played around with this for a while and it looks like it isn't going to happen for a bit. The scrollTo plugin works well enough for what we need.
any thoughts?
Taken care of since resetting the dependency to github master branch for node-irc.

Added count in title. Needs two things:
- Get rid of `(0)` when no unread messages
- Count all unread private messages, even if it's not a mention

These are both done.

One more thing: even for the active tab, messages should not be counted as read if the window is out of focus.
There ought to be a way to detect window focus with JS... I hope.
I read the diff and its looks good.

Sounds are now in.

Two more features remain:
- Don't mark read when window is not in focus
- Try desktop notifications
Hmm it is working for me...maybe I have unpushed work?

Here are some of the regressions I have seen:
- Userlist behavior is unusual, idle/active icons not working as expected
- There are at times the same user listed several times in the userlist
- Links embedding not working.
Works for me now, maybe was just broken in the middle of my refactoring... _shrug_
The userlist regressions are odd. Do you think the work that I did last night caused that?
I have fixed the userlist issues and the embedded media working on getting unread_mentions working correctly again.
Use the 'part' icon.

One issue: sound fires for a new private chat, even if I start it. This shouldn't happen.
_Update_: fixed.

For marking read when in focus, there's a new browser API for that sort of thing -- it's in Chrome, and just added to Firefox with FF10.
Done. Also upgraded underscore to 1.3.1 (a necessary prereq for Backbone 0.9.0).

Seems that references to `this.$()` elements are broken in Backbone 0.9.0 for some reason.
Reverted to 0.5.3 in master, and created a separate branch for testing 0.9.0.
Added in x buttons.
The X buttons look good but I think they should only be displayed when the user hovers over a tab. I am thinking about how to do this.
I resolved this with some of the userlist updates.

That's trivial with the :hover pesudo-class
http://reference.sitepoint.com/css/pseudoclass-hover

I'll leave this to you, if you want to take a stab at it... I want to investigate Backbone 0.9 issues. LMK if you have questions.
I might roll that back until I have a good idea how to do it. You would need two hover states, one for the tab and one for the actual button itself.
Closest possible match to what? Would the user specify a nick for their friend when they get the link?
Done -- see my pull request.

After using setElement() and wrapping chat template, it works.

The former method of assigning this.el to the chat template happened to work, but it's evident that Backbone wasn't designed with that in mind -- it should be a single element, whereas the former chat template had two root elements.
Yeh in essence I could just send you a link and then you would be able to follow it and would end up in a room.
I'll go ahead and take a look at this tomorrow morning.

Yeah, that part I got. But the "closest possible match for that username" part is a little odd. I'd think that when the user follows the link, we would need a prompt asking for desired username (assuming it's a first-time user).
Its really for people with no technical ability, they would just get dropped in the channel and then have that username.
You rock. High five.

Changed top bars & input to be fixed height with absolute positioning. I think the fluid sizing can cause issues at very small horizontal sizes as well, but that's a relatively minor issue, and not likely to occur with normal usage.

We've got the dependency switched, and the backend is supporting this. Have a console.log statement dumping the error object when a connection failure happens (errno ENOTFOUND). The remaining task is translating that, and any other error states, into a good error message for the end user.

A Twitter Bootstrap alert would be nice here.

I like this idea its probably a good idea to this with /part as well make the following all the same:

/part /wc /close
What clients support `/wc` and `/close`?
Just pushed a commit to add `/privmsg` & `/query`.
/wc and /close are supported by irssi and weechat
Added /wc & /close.
In addition to / rather than autocomplete on typing, a dropdown/select menu would be nice.
That would work too. We would still need a way for them to type in a server if they wanted though.
There was an issue with the template the userlist should be working now.
This issue is getting more important.

That's exactly the domain I want  :-)

.io domains aren't cheap though
Changed title from jQuery to simply Mobile -- since we could actually do this much better in a customized bottom up approach using H5BP Mobile Boilerplate and a grid system with media queries.
If you wanted to help with that, that would be awesome!
I think at the moment it is more important just to get the frontend client working well before we worry about a mobile version.

@niftylettuce, can you elaborate a bit on where we need support for HTML5 tags?

I'm familiar with H5BP, and I like it a lot as a reference. I'm just not sure what Subway is missing that extra html tags would solve.

@niftylettuce I think it's worth experimenting with how to scale the app down to mobile sizing via media queries and such. @thedjpetersen will probably have our hands full with other tasks for the time being, but I'd really like to see it happen. Feel free to play with that.

I think the design lends itself to downscaling pretty well by simply cutting out the two sidebars and making the central column occupy the whole screen on mobile. The hard part, then, is how to make those other two columns accessible. Popovers or slide-in panels would probably be best for those.
@thedjpetersen Did you want to try some custom alert style here? Or shall I just put in a twitter bootstrap alert message?
fixed!
I think the twitter bootstrap alert would be fine.

Just did a little exeriment with `document.mozHidden`. Turns out this doesn't work as expected -- it continues to return false if you focus on other windows and such. It only returns true if you change browser tabs.
Just took a peek at this... it looks nice, but I think it looks too much like a button. I tried to click it.
Ok I will start playing with it. If I can find another way to display it might be better.
So I have tried a few other designs but I cannot find something better. I think we are going to have to stick with this for the time being.
This is getting merged. Full steam ahead.

Messages are now considered unread if window is not in focus.

I'll consider this implemented no. Desktop notifications are still only in Chrome; may revisit those again if at least Firefox also gets support. Besides, those are more tricky -- they would be annoying if overdone.
done!

I'm sorry I'm extremely busy lately, just wanted to let you know this is on my mind but it is unclear when I'll have the chance to go through it all.  Eventually I will get sick of IRCCloud and develop the hell out of this.
Closing for reasons related to https://github.com/thedjpetersen/subway/issues/58 -- but yes I have many ideas for this down the road :)

Looked into this extensively, and can reproduce on Nodester but not locally. Now have a bug on the Nodester repo to see if anyone there can figure it out: https://github.com/nodester/nodester/issues/304

Deploy done... but with issues. Might not be solvable on our end, we shall see.
I'm gonna go ahead and close this, because it doesn't address issues with the software itself.

Agreed, other similar apps (where closing the window means losing connection to a real-time service) have a warning like this.

Otoh, with persistent connection, closing the window might not be so destructive. Hmm....
Ok I'll try to plan accordingly around that.

An easy fix for this might be a

```
process.on 'uncaughtException', log_err
```

See: https://github.com/proksoup/Hardboiled/blob/master/app.coffee#L13

Is what I usually do as a good start towards that without requiring additional monitoring/restarting. I've found it to be very stable for all of my random apps I build on heroku/nodejitsu/joyent (e.g. http://kickbackcard.com , http://cards.ly , http://hardboiled.nodejitsu.com , http://hardboiled.heroku.com , http://proksoup.com , http://insanelylucky.com all use it and all just responded for me just now despite some use and crappy code in all of them :) 

But I didn't do a pull request because I'm unsure if it's a "bad practice" since I don't see hardly anyone else doing it :)

@proksoup Thanks for the suggestion.

I'm sure others are doing it, because it's mentioned right in the node.js docs:
http://nodejs.org/docs/latest/api/process.html#event_uncaughtException_

So I guess that one line of code would prevent crashes... though other libraries might be useful for good logging of those exceptions when they do occur.

I think that notices should stay in the channel where the originated. For example, many bots send messages as notices (because the irc spec says bots should never respond to notices as a normal message.)
@niftylettuce are you interested in maybe trying to implement this?

Can you provide an issue description for this? The title is a little ambiguous.
Thanks.
The logo on the left sidebar could be a link to navigate back to the dashboard. I found myself trying to click it to go back.

Is the intention to connect to a different IRC network?

I think an explicit disconnect button might be better, as disconnecting is a destructive action; the "logo navigates to the home page" paradigm doesn't feel right in a single-page app like this IMO.
Okay good point
sure
Your server needs to be 'irc.freenode.net'
I know _that_, but through my stupidity, I found that, if you do enter an incorrect server, the messages pop up over and over again, even if you've stopped trying to connect.
Ah ok, I am seeing it as well now. I'll try to track it down.
Also experienced this.

It's socket.io behavior.  http://groups.google.com/group/socket_io/browse_thread/thread/5315a2978f31868e/ffda8fd107c1b35b?lnk=raot&pli=1

I have a fork that applies the suggested fix from that thread, but doesn't entirely solve the issue.
Thanks!

At the moment we have only programmed it to use a mongodb backend. It would probably take about a day though to make a version that uses couchdb.
Thanks I will try to get to this in the next couple of days.

beberlei,

I've looked into CouchDB a bit recently, but never worked with it. What would be the advantage (for the user) to a separate individual database? And where would the average user set one up? If it requires hosting your own Couch instance on your own server, the audience for that would be pretty small.

Also, consider that the unified DB model does bring with it one big advantage: you can see channel history even when you're not present in the channel.
You can signup with a free couchdb platform such as http://www.iriscouch.com/
I am a little confused what is the issue this is resolving?
Just curious what are some of the problems that could crop up?
You might be using a particular version locally and developing subway based on that and there might be a latest version in npm which can break that.

https://github.com/thedjpetersen/subway/blob/master/assets/js/views/chat_application.js#L19
At this point using the latest versions of all the packages should be fine, it seems to me that this would be a problem that would manifest itself pretty clearly, when it becomes a problem.

Cool. I did end up finding your code that implements it.

That's why I originally didn't know about it...

Derek,

I'm on Chrome 17, though on a Mac. May be a platform-specific bug, or maybe it's cropping up in specific circumstances.
Are you able to test a bit under Firefox, and try some different scenarios, so we can narrow down what's causing this?

Yeah, I'll look into it, maybe tonight.

I didn't totally understand the way you were checking for an inactive tab.
Looked like you have a timer go off every second on window.blur until the tab is active again (I think).

Yes, the idea is that even if the tab is focused, it should be treated as if it's inactive as soon as the user blurs the window (to use another app etc.) so that new message notifications would be seen/heard.

I remember now... it's working as intended.

The intended behavior was that we would notify the user of unread PMs + unread mentions. I figured that titlebar notifications for all unread messages would be a little too intrusive... I view that (and the sounds we have) similar to new mail notifications -- they signify messages aimed at you.

What sort of behavior would be ideal to you?

I'm gonna go ahead and pin down the packages.json to the version I have running locally. On NodeUp one of the devs said he spent hours tracking down a bug that was due to a dependency version difference. That doesn't sound like my idea of fun.
done

And the reason for the timer is that blur is fired even if the user clicks on browser chrome (like the location bar), and I wanted to avoid it firing on quick switches to things like that. It might make sense to extend it a bit.

Ah, cool.
I kinda like the idea, but I'm not sure there's a significant benefit to most users. At least when you consider the time investment vs. other issues.

The biggest upside I see is that it alleviates resource/disk capacity stress on a single server. But otoh, it also makes the shared channel logging impossible.
@thedjpetersen Is this resolved with commit d84f?

I think it's an issue related to IMEs (Input Method Editors) for languages like Chinese & Japanese. I've used them before.
I'll test this one out.

In an IME, keyboard input initially enters a middle state, where characters are auto-converted to kanji, etc. based on the IME's best guess at the words you intend. You make modifications, then typically press enter to confirm that string. After that, enter can be used as usual for the text field.

OK, so I tested it with PMs/mentions and it does work.

I thought it would work for any message (not joins/parts) as well :)

No biggie though... the behavior you've implemented is good.
OK cool, we'll stick with what we've got for now then.  :-)
thanks!
Does it usually happen after a small amount of inactivity? This might be a focus issue.

It has happened after inactivity, but I know of at least one instance where I was in a steady conversation in a /query, with little/no pauses and I saw in my terminal that the JSON was getting PRIVMSG'd to the channel above (to my mild embarrassment).

So inactivity may be one cause, as that had happened before, but not necessarily.

There might've been a pause between two messages, but I doubt the mid-conversation misdirection was due to any changes in UI focus.

I had to hack it almost the same way trying to get it to talk to my bouncer.  I ended up just adding some form fields to the login page for port and password, then passing those through to the irc module.

(course, connecting to my bouncer leads to more issues, like the fact not all the messages make it through on connect to webui, but those can be solved)

Found a potential cause, appeared to occur when the network and/or my computer was slowing down.

This is lame as hell, but I can't actually determine which of those symptoms caused it at the time, but it definitely seemed related when it occurred.

I would recommend simulating packet loss/connection loss, and if that doesn't reproduce it, try loading the machine down.
This is probably a client side error, can you get the trace from the chrome debugger?

Just added in the code to catch uncaught exceptions.
Should hopefully prevent the obscure bugs we've been seeing from bringing down the application.
This should be taken care of now with this fix: https://github.com/thedjpetersen/subway/commit/afff83eb0414452ca007546166d8b570d85f8b31
I'd like to add, that there are no messages coming through from a user that changed its nick until it changes back.

The initial error comes from the ircd you're connecting to, you're hitting a class limit of how many connections are allowed.

Subway should probably handle this case better, but you need to inform the irc network that they'll need to allow more simultaneous connections from your ip.
Also clients whose nick is forcibly changed by the network cease to update
Cool, thanks for the info!
see code attached to #97 does not handle certificates currently, I don't see a reason to work too hard on that until the settings are handled.
Should surface this error in the UI. I'll look into it.

Thanks for working on this. Just tried it out locally, it seems to work just fine. No clues about the SSL status in the app or logs though... it would help if we added something.

One issue I have, that should be rectified before we merge this into master: the UI has a blank input for the port, implying that the field requires input... there's no hint that it will supply the correct port if you leave it blank. I'd like to see that change so the port is pre-filled (and switches automatically when you check/uncheck SSL).

Another request: I think the port input and SSL checkbox should be combined onto the same line in the UI, as the port field doesn't need that much space. Should be easy with `.form-inline`: http://twitter.github.com/bootstrap/base-css.html#forms

Pushed a minimal solution to this. All it does it throw an alert box.

Much more could be done to improve the UI and handling of a disconnect, so I'll leave this open.

Some ideas for more elegant notification of a disconnect:
- Show red Bootstrap alert within/above chat window (should remain in place even if user switches chat windows)
- Fade out chat text
- Attempt/offer to auto-reconnect; if user declines, return to connect dialog.

This is something that would need to be implemented in the IRC module first. Specifically by changing the [net.createConnection parameters](https://github.com/martynsmith/node-irc/blob/b30e1f6e22cb0fabd1125afdb0fecce3f23f646c/lib/irc.js#L611) to accept an [options object](http://nodejs.org/api/net.html#net_net_createconnection_options_connectionlistener) instead of port and host. I don't know of a way to implement it for TLS as well, otherwise I would write the patch myself.

You would also want to add localAddress support to Socket.io (I don't see any documentation for it at least) and to the webserver ([add an IP after the port in server.listen()](https://github.com/thedjpetersen/subway/blob/5bfefdcb573694852eecbfbc98db941a2f127cbb/lib/webserver.js#L35))

Okay so this is an issue with the version of nodejs that ubuntu installs from it's standard repo.

So don't use it, and if you've already installed it, remove it.

You want to get the latest stable version, and can do so on Ubuntu 12.x with the following steps:

sudo apt-get install python-software-properties python g++ make
sudo add-apt-repository ppa:chris-lea/node.js
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install nodejs

Once you have that, `npm install` should run correctly. and a `nodejs subway` should start subway.

## Update packages and install Node.js

sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install python-software-properties python g++ make
sudo add-apt-repository ppa:chris-lea/node.js
sudo apt-get install nodejs=0.10.18-1chl1~precise1

## Install NPM (Node.js package manager)

curl https://npmjs.org/install.sh | sudo sh

@badosu could you take a quick look at this since you added the `client_port` attribute?

> For example, will I not be able anymore to run subway on heroku with this patch?

Definitely not. On the contrary, I'm making this change to prevent custom configuration for Heroku-like systems (I use Dokku).

The point is, `client_port` is always the port you get from `document.location.port` since we listen on the same port with the asset server.

If you think this will break your setup, feel free to get this fork and push it to Heroku but again, I did this to be able to run this on my Dokku server which runs smoothly, without any configuration change.

Is'nt it possible to support Dokku **and** support people who can't use websockets as well?

I am totally into supporting a new infrasctructure provider, but removing support for another or the fallback for websockets, as a consequence, does not seem a good idea.

Also, this would revert #226 too.

@badosu, this is **not** removing support for Heroku or anything else. Even if you don't use websockets, you still use the same port on the client: `document.location.port`.

And it does not revert #226 either. We still use the port provided by the environment. Dokku is not a new provider, it is just an open source Heroku clone which has exactly the same properties with it except for the websocket limitation: https://github.com/progrium/dokku
So it is ok for me. :+1:

@badosu, if this regresses anything related to Heroku or other service, I give you my word that I'll fix it ;)

@thedjpetersen: It is pretty easy:
The client sends _before_ the USER/NICK/PASS a WEBCHAT like with the following syntax:
WEBIRC [password] [username] [hostname] [ip]
And the IRCd changes the user hostname/ip to the one specified in the webirc line.
(The password is configured on the ircd side and hostname is the resolved ip of the user)
